bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to W.H.W. Komp, June 23, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] discusses the breeding of mosquitoes in streams and ponds.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to W.H.W. Komp, June 23, 1923
div1.opener:
I. W
Komp.
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
June 23/23.
Mr. W. H. W. Komp,
Sanitary Engineer,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Box 231, Crowley, La.
Dear Mr. Komp:
div1.p:
For some reason your letter of the 11th. inst. was delayed in
reaching me.

Since during our work in the neighborhood of large ponds in the
so-called “falls regions” of the South we have not found in many--
certainly over 200--examinations, A. quad. breeding of “sanitary
importance” in any free running stream (or small pool) and since
they do breed in such streams elsewhere, one of two conclusions is
allowable:
1/ The breeding habits of this species differ in this matter
for different regions or
2/ That it is a preferential, but not obligatory pond breeder.

Neither is improbably ie. there is analogy for it,, but I am inclined to think that the latter
is more probable.

If I am right, and the pond is the preferential breeding place,
the fact that its breeding was confined to ponds where we were work-
ing is due, not to any objection to streams, but to the attraction
of the pond: and this seems the more probable as in the low country
where ponds were not available we have found them breeding in seepage
areas and small marshes. I have not seen them however in free run-
ning streams ever here

You can readily determine whether this difference is regional or
due to preference for a particular class of breeding places--i. e. ponds--
by noting in the low country the conditions under which they breed:
1/ Where there are no ponds:
2/ Where there are.

I have done much more work in the “falls region” than in the low
country and in the former A. quad. is very rare except in ponds.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General,
(On waiting orders).
